newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee ends tightly mixed.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee ends tightly mixed.

text.p: LIFFE coffee futures were tightly mixed by the close on Friday with prices holding well below their peaks after a bout of fund buying early in the session.
Traders said price movements were rather restricted in the afternoon after New York arabica futures started off the day on a slightly weaker tone.
While there was a widespread feeling that London could have been overbought after this week's rally, there were very few sellers amid frost fears in Brazil in the coming weeks.
Benchmark July was up $4 at $2,086 per tonne and September eased $2 to $2,098.
The second-month July raced to an intraday high of $2,110 but failed to match Thursday's peak of $2,145.
Activity remained light before a three-day holiday weekend in the U.S. and Britain, with total volume at 3,567 lots.
New York and London markets are closed on Monday, reopening on Tuesday.
While the weather forecasts point to a much colder weather moving into Brazil's coffee belt on Friday, no damaging cold was expected.
Traders said coffee benefitted from light fund buying. With coffee charts still looking extremely bullish in the longer-term, traders said funds were keen to buy on dips.
Technical analysts said even if July pulls back about another $80, robustas would still look bullish and likely head toward $2,300. They said support rests near $2,010.
Options activity was also signalling further gains to new highs. Traders said investors have been buying out-of-the-money calls this week at strikes above $2,000.
At-the-money implied September options volatility was pegged near 60 percent, up sharply from about 44 percent a week ago but in-line with historical levels.
Fundamentally, coffee continued to get a boost from signs the world's tight coffee supply situation in coffee was not expected to ease in the near-term.

"We expect a certain tightness in the market, especially for the period from July to September," the Association of Coffee Producing Countries' secretary general Robeiro Oliveira Silva told reporters at the International Coffee Organization's meeting here on Friday.
